content.body: Hixie: thanks for the changes
Ah, Whataburger, the most Texan of all fast-food joints.
is filling up on stereotypical food.
Hey all
hey
Hey Hixie, how's it goin' tonight?

Hixie: if you can indulge me, there's another minor issue in the markup for the HTML5 spec that I'd hope you can fix upstream -- it's that there's no "type" attribute on the style element that contains the .domintro:before selector
JonathanNeal: good, good, you?
MikeSmith: updating...
MikeSmith: are you fixing the pubrules checker issues that the webmaster pointed out?
The battle of HTML5 seems all but over within the company, we're good to go.  I've been building out the next version of the theme that ships with the product.
MikeSmith: (sounds like you are, just wanted to confirm)
JonathanNeal: what is your company's product and/or service?
Liferay, our company site is all HTML5'd out now, but now I've been working to put it in the product.

Along with moving off TABLE-based layouts, and so far it all looks good.  Today I built the new default theme that will ship with the next version of the software coming out later this month or sometime about then.
othermaciej: yeah, plh fixed a bunch and I'm fixing more now
othermaciej: scare quotes implied
I always forget who each of you guys work for, it seems to be a pretty well mixed bunch.
othermaciej:  in some cases we're not really fixing anything, but instead just trying to get the pubrules checker to stfu
MikeSmith: fixed
MikeSmith: that's unfortunate, glad things are getting fixed though
Hixie: thanks again
othermaciej: a number of the drafts are already in place at the 2010/WD-* URLs, so we just need to wait for the webmaster to add symlinks for those
the rest I should have in place well before the html wg telcon tonight
MikeSmith: hawt
othermaciej, what do you do?
JonathanNeal: I'm on the WebKit team at Apple
Oh neato, I like you guys *except that whole gradient spec* :D
I blame TabAtkins for the gradient spec
Really?  TabAtkins did it?  Say it ain't so.  He helped move me to HTML5.
othermaciej, fine, can I blame you for your quicktime-ish HTML5 video player?
JonathanNeal: I think he's currently editing the gradient spec, though I think we were the first to have some form of gradients in CSS
othermaciej: i saw that this issue http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/10 was closed w/o prejudice
and i was just curious whether that means no consideration was taken regarding SMIL?
(i'm just trying to figure out what the status is atm, besides, you know, closed)
JonathanNeal: what aspect of our video player do you find too "quicktime-ish"?
http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-video-framing/ othermaciej
knowtheory: no one made a concrete proposal to make the <video> element more like SMIL
knowtheory: if someone were to come forward with a proposal, we could reopen it, though at this point I'd suggest any proposals along those lines start with a bug report
othermaciej: great, that's what i wanted to know.
i'm disappointed that Dick Bulterman never got back to you guys
JonathanNeal: that's not what the latest controls look like
i work w/ a startup who's doing SMIL based video delivery, and when i found this, i thought it was both interesting, and potentially useful
especially if there is interoperability between SMIL and (X)HTML5
I'll either update or delete the page when the next Safari is out then.
knowtheory: for what it's worth, I think a proposal to incompatibly change the core features of <video> and <audio> would have a huge uphill battle at this point
othermaciej, will there be keyboard controls, do you know?
JonathanNeal: in Safari 4.04 on SnowLeopard, the controls I get on the live video do not look anything like your screenshot
You don't need to answer that, I'll find out when I find out.
othermaciej: yeah i appreciate that (which is why i'm particularly disappointed that Bulterman never got back to you guys), i figure i should at least take a look
othermaciej, oh I guess it's a PC thing.

we're interested in adoption of SMIL, but if that can be accomplished by better coordiation w/ existing standards, and being able to do things like integrate SMIL timing semantics via XML modules, so much the better IMO
JonathanNeal: we might not have updated Safari on Windows to the new controls yet
You might be interested in seeing http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-layout/7cogs-website.html it's filled with all sorts of HTML5 / CSS3 -webkit goodness.
-moz goodness too, even some IE love.
JonathanNeal: the controls are not keyboardable by default if that is your concern
but the look and hover behavior are different
othermaciej: i apologize for being out of the loop on this, i've only really started paying attention to the HTML5 process in earnest recently, i wish i had tuned in sooner :\
(apologize for raising this issue at this late stage that is)
knowtheory: I am just giving you fair warning that you may not have much luck if you propose incompatible changes
unless you have a really really really compelling rationale
JonathanNeal: nice looking web page
othermaciej: Thanks, i appreciate that, and don't really expect anything, but again, squandering the opportunity seems just as foolish, if something amenable could be worked out.
othermaciej: btw, i see that last call for comments is out, when is that process going to draw to a close?
knowtheory: the WHATWG copy of the spec went into Last Call, but then converted to unversioned, so I am not sure what the plan is there
at the W3C, the spec is not yet in Last Call
the stability is just marked section-by-section
going to last call was really a shorthand for saying all the sections were in last call
Ah okay, thanks.
(you can see the states in the margins of the whatwg spec)
I saw the Status there under http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/video.html#video
so i wasn't sure, exactly what the implications of Last Call were here
"Larry wrote 2 March 2010 member-only email with suggested path forward (for some reason, it's not in the tag⊙wo archives, hence not linkable from this agenda)
knowtheory: oh you don't want to look at the version on the TR/ page, that's almost always out of date
does anyone know if the email in question is available elsewhere?

(again i apologize that i haven't had more time to poke around and find out what the W3C process is yet, i saw that the relevant ticket was closed 2 months ago, and wanted to pop in to find out if it was too late to do anything)
context: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2010Mar/0011.html
Hixie: where should i be looking then?
knowtheory: you want either http://whatwg.org/html or http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/
othermaciej, thanks
ah fantastic thanks Hixie
the former has a feedback form in the lower right which might be useful
Cool, much appreciated
hsivonen: interesting - haven't seen the email, but then I looked at the February tag archives and found much fascinating content
othermaciej: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/tag/2010Feb/0065.html and http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/tag/2010Feb/0057.html in particular
hsivonen: I'm wary of linking specific emails lest there be complaints that discussion on secret lists isn't being kept secret enough
sorry. I thought in was common practice to point to the URLs.
Incidentally othermaciej & Hixie is the HTML5 group aware of XHTML+SMIL? http://www.w3.org/TR/XHTMLplusSMIL/
hsivonen: me too but apparently it gets some people's panties in a bunch
hsivonen: you shouldn't feel the need to stop doing so
I'm just explaining why I am not doing so at the moment
I see
knowtheory: SMIL has been raised from time to time, but no ones seems particularly interested and its not clear what problems it would solve or how to integrate it with HTML
hsivonen: the emails you linked are indeed particularly interesting
foolip: Funnily enough, those are all questions i'm seeking to answer ;)
knowtheory: there was some discussion in the a11y taskforce not too long ago, perhaps you can search the archives
a11y?  I will do some googling, anything you could recommend i look for specifically?
ah the accessibility group
knowtheory: for reference (i.e. if you want to hit me), I'm Philip Jägenstedt in those threads.
thanks :) much appreciated.
knowtheory: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-a11y/
thanks MikeSmith
knowtheory: my impression is the same as Philip's; people are generally aware of SMIL, but there is not much interest in using it
Yep, i appreciate that.
SMIL is a classic case of a W3C WG doing its own thing without enough implementors of incumbent products participating
Yeah, i've spent the past 3 months researching wtf happened w/ the SMIL standard
what it can do, what it can't do, how it interacts w/ other standards
what can it do?
in practice i mean
are there .js implementations yet?
well, SMIL's general purpose is to provide general timing semantics in a declarative fashion
there are some components of SMIL that have been built by people here and there
the only bit i've historically been interested in was timed text, which wasn't even in the older standards, they deferred to whatever realaudio etc happened to consume
so i'm curious if http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/CR-ttaf1-dfxp-20100223/ will get any traction
yeah.  the SMIL3 standard has timed text as a module at this point
and happy it got renamed to something saner
i mean most people know that some of SMIL's timing semantics have been integrated into SVG
<- http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-tt/2010Feb/0004.html
in order to do very basic animation
DFXP/TTML is pretty weird too, at least the styling markup
yeah i'm aware of TTML though not the details of how weird it can get.
DFXP has the worst acronym I have ever seen for a technology
the thing w/ SMIL is that it can provide basic timing semantics, which is handy for a variety of tasks, and is particularly useful when coordinating multiple pieces of content
i can give you examples of what the company i work for has been doing, and is pushing to continue to do
if people are interested
my impression of SMIL is that it feels like something designed for the era of multimedia CD-ROMs
othermaciej: that's sort of true, and sort of not.  My biggest complaint about SMIL right now is that the layout tools feel really clunky
it doesn't seem to fit that well with what people want to do with animation or timed media today
The expansion of DFXP is not very helpful either: Distribution Format Exchange Profile
which is why i'm getting interested in the possibility of integrating SMIL timing semantics into something with a more mature layout model, like XHTML
I think what people want is things that integrate really well into HTML/CSS, not a new top-level technology
Well that's the thing, since SMIL's been modularized it's actually possible to pick and choose components to support
if it's possible to integrate the standards at a base level
I don't view that as a plus
but HTML has no namespaces, so we'd just be copying the element names
picking and choosing what components to support leads to fragmentation and lack of interoperability
Yes, i'm going to have to admit, that i am walking into this somewhat unprepared so i dn't know that i have all the answers or a firm grasp of where the points of pain would be for integration.
othermaciej: yeah, well w/ SMIL it's used on such a wide variety of platforms with such a wide variety of capabilities
the design of DFXP is really sad. unfortunately, the spec fills a current accessibility void, so there's a risk that the Web gets stuck with it
they basically had to modularize the standard
MMS functions through SMIL for instance
at least some uses of SMIL actually support such tiny subsets that it's almost silly to pretend they are SMIL
MMS is a good example
does anyone use MMS?
In this day?  Probably not

Apple initially considered putting some SMIL support into WebKit to do it but the subset actually supported and used on real phones is so trivial that it was easier to just handle the common special cases

I mean, at this point there's like 3 issues.  First is why is SMIL the way it is (given it's history), second is what does SMIL actually provide to users at large, and 3rd, is it worth supporting and/or does it have a future as a tech
othermaciej: sure, i think that there is something to be said for being able to declaritively define timed behavior
the other alternative being JS
Depending on what your environment is, and whom your accepting data from, being able to rely on just recieving XML is a good thing
there's also css animations and css transitions
although those do not have SMIL's more robust concept of timebases
yeah.  A lot of what we're trying to do specifically involves video, and being able to manipulate it in a variety of ways
which is why we're interested in what's happening w/ HTML5
and SMIL's semantics for doing stuff like that are really good, if you want to concatenate video, or play video along side each other in a single timed environment
it's pretty solid
again i need to look at the issue more regarding HTML5s behavior, but i'm not sure how easy something like that would be to do w/ the in browser players that exist now
there are a bunch of toy usecases that exist already (i've been thinking about this because i intend to talk to people about it at SxSWi)
for instance, a youtube doubler would be easy to do in SMIL
and offer better control over timing
than the existing youtube doubler, which relies on remoting in and out of the flash player w/ JS (although that'll probably change w/ the HTML5 player and direct JS access)
'doubler'?
knowtheory: concatenation - you'd have to use script
knowtheory: it seems the difficult part here is actually getting media to play in sync or concatented without gaps, not the syntax for expressing it
knowtheory: playing side-by-side - there is no good way to tell the media engine to keep the timebases in sync
othermaciej: SMIL sets up semantics for dealing with slippage incidentally
othermaciej: s/the media engine/QuickTime/ ? or more generally?
ah http://www.youtubedoubler.com/ :)
othermaciej: what is "the media engine"? it seems to be possible in e.g. GStreamer.
sorry danbri was looking for a particular one to link you to
but you beat me to the site
here danbri: http://www.youtubedoubler.com/?video1=http://www.youtube.com/v/HsF_2CNV9v4&start1=3&video2=http://www.youtube.com/v/06CvUjLgK5g&start2=0&h=1
foolip: btw, thanks for the replies about the surveys. I have to say I'm a bit confused about whether the issues you brought up were discussed previously among the media subgroup members
hsivonen, foolip: I mean there is no good interface at the HTML level
othermaciej: here's an example i found out today that a friend of mine hacked up of a presentation using HTML5's audio: http://labs.toolness.com/ff-herdict-preso/
I know media playback engines *can* keep playback in sync if told do so, there is just no way to tell them
i told him i'd put that example together a SMIL version of that as well
othermaciej: indeed, but that isn't the hard part IMO, the hard part is in the media framework
knowtheory: syncing with a slideshow type thing is doable - though we have also discussed better ways to do it than the best currently possible
oh yeah?
that'd be interesting to hear about

MikeSmith: I think it's mostly been me, Silvia and Eric discussing the technical details, so there are plenty of small issues. But I don't think it's meaningful to make it perfect since things will likely be remade after it hits the HTML WG anyway.
would like to see it hit the HTML WG ASAP
too
subtitle format debates scare me
knowtheory: there used to be a concept of "cue ranges"
annevk: which parts do you find scary?
annevk: I would lean towards HTML5 being agnostic about supported formats
othermaciej: that doesn't really address the problem that we need a format the all the relevant vendors agree to implement
othermaciej: especially if the format is external to the video file
since in that case there's no value in maintaining the MPEG vs. Xiph duality
hsivonen: I expect all vendors will support SRT
I think no browser vendor has found SRT objectionable, yet
it's just that it lacks a spec
othermaciej: original SRT or RSSesquely extended?
hsivonen: I expect over time we will also agree on either DXFP or perhaps a subset, but I am less sure of that
I think trying to encode either or both of those thoughts in the HTML5 spec is likely to spawn flamewars
RSS <title> all over again scares me
say no SRT extensions!
agrees with foolip
I do not really care, but if it lacks a spec, I suppose someone should make one
if we can cover all relevant use cases with some SRT extensions that seems favorable over DXFP
and I think we shouldn't support the pseudo-HTML typically found in SRT either
we'll need some kind of SRT spec to nail all those things down
SRT?
annevk: I'd be OK with having a position up vs. position down marker extension in SRT, but the pseudo-HTML is serious badness
I expect writing the parsing section for SRT would be fun given the weird stuff that existing in the wild
hsivonen: position could be done with CSS couldn't it?
hsivonen: I mean completely external to the SRT file
foolip, that'd suck

(I can believe that position up vs. down could be dressed into being a legal requirement, but I have really hard time believing italics is a legal requirement unless someone shows me the relevant chapter and verse in a statute)
foolip, you want the ability to move the subtitles around a little to not cover onscreen text
foolip: I meant positioning a particular string in a particular time window near the top of the video frame when the video frame itself has relevant text at the bottom
knowtheory: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SubRip
I don't really like the idea of pushing SRT towards the "complex" side of the scale, I'd much rather have one format on each extreme
i.e. SRT + something
thanks MikeSmith :)
these legal requirements that are cited from time to time, who do they apply to? TV stations? Set-top box makers? Browser vendors?
So there's an interest in subtitles/captioning on video?
foolip: government bodies definitely
knowtheory: yes, very much so
i believe that companies also have an obligation
but i'm not sure what it is.
(off the top of my head anyway)
the laws change from country to country but by and large they do apply to private organisations as well
So it could be illegal to not support e.g. positioning subtitles in a software product? That doesn't sound very reasonable.
foolip: i'm trying to catch up with the discussion in progress here :) there are accessibility requirements that vary from country to country, is what i'm saying
Okay so basically, I should go justify SMIL's existence ;) and then see whether there's any interest (or even a way) to propose some kind of interoperability w/ HTML5
knowtheory: even if you manage to justify SMIL's existence, it's not a given that it's the most appropriate syntax for text/html.
hsivonen: in what contexts?
knowtheory: it's not a given that mixing SMIL syntax into text/html is a good idea even if SMIL turned out to have some desirable features
Actually, what is the deal with XHTML5?  someone made mention of a flath namespace?
XHTML5 is the HTML5 language parsed through an XML parser
Yeah, i get that
supports nameespaces and all that fun stuff then right?
so XHTML5 should support imbedding SVG
or a SMIL document as a result?
syntactically, yes
(even if browsers wouldnt' know what to do with the content)
yes, fine
knowtheory: see the very end of http://hsivonen.iki.fi/xhtml2-html5-q-and-a/
why do we care about SMIL?
Because HTML5 is converging on the media space, which is what SMIL was made for
and because SMIL does things like provide timing semantics which don't really exist in other standards
timing semantics. in this specific example, the synching of captions to video, but there are many other applications.
and because SMIL is already integrated into other standards, like SVG
I'm not saying that HTML5 has to support it, but i'd like to try to make a case
that it might be useful/cool if it did
And i'm not suggesting that HTML5 should contain SMIL :P
I was just curious whether there was a possibility for interoperability given this issue: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/10
SVG uses a forked subset of SMIL, not SMIL proper
Yes, there's a common functional base though
hmm, maybe somewhat
foolip: thanks for the link
jgraham: http://www.petapixel.com/2010/03/03/canon-l-lens-look-alike-coffee-mug/
hey, is there any way to measure the extremities of a drawing on canvas
like so i can scale it correctly?
mut: No
(other than keeping track of it manually in your scripts)
was XMLHttpRequest once specified in HTML5?
othermaciej: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/2005-09-01/#scripted-http
Philip` ok cheers... :(
whoah, I didn't know there were historical copies of the spec on whatwg.org
is there any way to see what previous versions exist?
try url-hacking
the 2006 version also has xhr
were Workers ever in HTML5 or were they always separate (can't remember)
here is my list of specs spun off from HTML5 so far:
othermaciej, http://www.whatwg.org/specs/ has copies
othermaciej, Web Workers was always separate, though is part of Web Applications 1.0 now
s/copies/pointers/
- 2dcontext, microdata, server-sent events, web messaging, web sockets api, web sockets protocol, web sql data base, web storage, xmlhttprequest
now that I typed that I realize I am missing the sniffing spec
workers was initially a separate source doc but was later merged with the main source (but has never been part of the generated html5 spec)
can anyone else think of specs that got split out besides what I listed?
I guess there is also Web Addresses, though that is in a messed up state
also are any of what I listed wrong?
window was split but merged back
I don't think it was ever actually removed from the spec, though I did try to write a separate spec for it at one point
selectors api was originally an issue marker in the html5 spec, though there was never any normative prose written for it in the html5 spec
the alternative stylesheet stuff in cssom
the url stuff
the origin stuff
<device>
the internet
oh wait
anybody know any Hadoop committers, or anybody involved with Hadoop that might be interested in doing a presentation about it?
annevk5: btw, thank you for having the html5-diff doc pubrules-clean (unlike me, who got a serious beat-down yesterday for not having the h:tml doc in the proper state)
Hixie, in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html#protocol-overview the ABNF does not look nice
hmm, maybe I don't have the correct fonts or something
"doesn't look nice"?
what doesn't look nice about it?
for some reason no monospace font is selected on my machine
the comment for the name-char production wraps in an unsightly way
that comment would be less prone to unsightliness if it were to be split into two lines
the any-char production risks potential unsightliness as well
*the comment for the any-char production
encoding as UTF-8 seems wrong btw for resource name
it would have to be percent-escaped i'd think
also, it seems the connection steps stop mentioning UTF-8 encoded from step 7 on
oh, nm
MikeSmith: i recommend getting a bigger monitor
that way it won't wrap ata ll
sets aside his iPhone and goes to check on his main work machine, a TTY
no luck there
i do not buy that you were looking at that page on your iphone
it's a 5MB HTML page of DOOM
<snort>
your iphone would probably catch fire if it didn't hang first
I don't even have an iPhone, actually
aha!
I would welcome the donation of one from a generous benefactor
Liar!
puts out his pants fire
but it does honestly look like crap on my TTY
and my Apple IIe
goes back to playing Wizardry
:/ just realised that the save() and restore()  functions on canvas are stacked
that could have saved me some time about 3 or 4 hours ago
how did you think they worked before?
one-off?
yea
dont laugh :P
anything in particular make you think that? if the spec is misleading i can try to fix it
nah im noob
everyone's a noob when they first read the spec, anything i can do to help noobs is helpful to many :-)
seems realy obvious now tbh
k
just didn't realise
Hixie: Make the spec shorter
just spotted it in a tutorial and facepalmed
gsnedders: press command+minus a few times
i love how canvas is similar to cnc gcode :) saved my learning curve
doesn't like how he knows nothing about 2D graphics APIs
Hixie: That's not really shorter by any useful metric
jgraham: he didn't specify
I reccommend doing s/[aeiou]//
It is srprsng hw sy it is t rd stff wth n vwls
You included "i" there.
Er, yes
I failk
Indeed. Like normal.
I isn't a real vowel anyway
No, you're jgraham.
Not much like a consunent either
And I still can't spell.
Was that supposed to say constanant?
Yes
Well at least the fail is spread around :)
jgraham made me take off my headphones :(
doesn't like that man in the corner
Oh you were probably only listening to Christian noisecore or some such anyway
I'm sure your ears thanked me
Within Temptation, actually
Though I guess symphoic metal is something you'll hate anyway
I mean, includes "metal" in the name of the genre
Much like Midge Ure, that means nothing to me
gsnedders: do you mean 'symphonic metal' by any chance?
heh canvas is ace, couldnt think of many applications to use it at first, but applications for it keep popping into my head
workmad3: Have I not already proven I cannot spell?
prefers operatic metal e.g. 'nightwish' personally
gsnedders: very true :)
workmad3: jgraham prefers the Eels and Radiohead.
But I guess he could tell you that.
Not exclusively
Well, I don't like sym[autocomplete this yourself]
metal
exclusively
I pressed return a bit too soon then
I mean, even the intersection of our music tastes manages to be a non-empty set.
the new stuff in the websocket protocol added 40 lines of code to my simple server
I don't like operatic metal exclusively... I'll listen to most rock or metal and enjoy it to some extent :)
gsnedders: Symbiotic metal?
I don't like RnB, hiphop, rap, or pop though
prefers plastic to metal
easier to stamp out the same thing time after time? :P
notes that gsnedders listed two bands and compared then to a genre
jgraham: Okay, okay… in 48 days I'll start being sensible.
Whatever "ikag" means.
Ijak
Or rather !Ijak
Whatever that word we were discussing earlier on the whiteboard means.
woo, my server returns the same handshake as the spec's example
sweet
Hixie: Congrats, you managed to write Perl without killing yourself.
ok time for bed
workmad3: how about folk metal?
I'm a hardcore fan of that folkmetal stuff
this kind of thing:
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/08/Skyforger_16127_Cernunnos_Fest_11.jpg
MikeSmith: You like Finntroll?
That's a real genre? What does it consist of? Metal riffs played on the banjo?
scrambles to look up Fintroll in Wikipedia
Hmm the photo suggests normal metal + bagpipes for more aural pain
jgraham: don't mock the gods of folktalic metal
Those bagpipes don't even have enough pipes to be very loud
Finntroll is damn near the ultimate folk metal band... combine metal with humppa and have finns singing in swedish, it's awesome :)
daedb: I am mostly a fan of the physique of the Fintrolls
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Finntroll%2C_Metaltown_2008.JPG
wonders what those guys eat, of if they do in fact eat
MikeSmith: I was at the concert where that photo was taken :)
daedb: I am pretty sure those dudes are tweakers
daedb: I don't actually know nothing about them.. I suppose I might seriously like them if I actually listened
or especially if I went to a live show
I actually expected them to be more fun live than they were, but it wasn't bad.
I've found there's a lot of music I don't really care about much if I listen to a recording, but can like it at lot of I see it live
metalheads
I saw this band a while back and there music is a joke but they actually they actually tore up seriously when they played live -
http://www.pinkypiglets.com/
jgraham: I'm pretty sure http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/08/Skyforger_16127_Cernunnos_Fest_11.jpg is actually a scene from the movie Spinal Tap
and if it's not, it should be
Sight. Metal. Can't live with it
*Sigh
Sigh
At least you've _listened_ to some, unlike too many people who slag it off endlessly.
jgraham: if you think you've seen the worst of it, try some Christian metal
that'll change your mind
Hey, there is some good Christian metal
hides
I don't mean to slag it off endlessly or anything. It's just that it seems to be what *all* the kids here (and by kids, I don't just mean gsnedders, I eman anyone under the age of 40) are into
"Christian metal" is kind of like "Satanic bake sale"
jgraham: Welcome to Sweden :P
Especially 80's christian metal, like Stryper :p
not to use the name of Lord Satan in vain, by the way
Nothing like some cookies of deatho or sponge cake of hell to brighten a rainy sunday morning
daedb: yes, the Stryper guys did indeed have some serious armadillos on their trowsers
Stryper did spandex better than anybody
In other news, the lack of takers for the Ukelele Orchestra is most disappointing
jgraham, how many people said they'd go?
Lachy: None
Unless gsnedders changes his mind I guess
I said I might.
s/changes/makes up/
Amazing how big signatures some people on public-html have
And how the readability of quote-heavy threads seems inversely proportional to how much the thread deals with a11y
jgraham, you just need to promote it better.

Dashiva: My understanding is that is because the requirements for making email understandable to blind users are the exact opposite of the requirements to make the conversations understandable to everyone else
This seems to be a deficiency in the email clients avaliable to the blind

would this be a good time (and place) to ask the Swedish Heavy Metal Gods a question re: alt attribute on images in a <figure>?
I was just wondering, from a usability p.o.v., would it be correct to state that an image in a <figure> should always have alternative text (in the 'alt' attribute)?
if someone could programmatically turn emotions in email into noise, you wouldn’t even need to write any music; just point it at public-html and press rec
davidhund__: The spec explicitly allows alt to be omitted if you're in a <figure> with a <figcaption>
But, this means that the figcaption could describe content that's 'not there', right?

and indicates it's the appropriate thing to do when you don't have a real textual alternative to the image (e.g. you don't know what's in the image) but you do have some other text that's related to the image (e.g. a title)
An with no alt isn't 'not there'
is not there, but just is unknown and dependent on context
(as I understand it)
hrm

I think the idea is that if you can replace the image with equivalent text, then that text goes in alt; otherwise you shouldn't specify alt at all (and shouldn't put in text that's descriptive but not equivalent - that should go in a <figcaption> instead)
How would be helpful to people with screenreaders?
Empty alt="" should only be used for decorative images or similar things where the image can be omitted entirely; you shouldn't use it in that example
exactly.
Hence my question: "Would it be correct to say that alt text is required on images in a <figure>"

No, because there are other examples where alt should be omitted (when it's impossible to do anything that would be helpful to people with screenreaders, and putting bogus alt text would be worse than omitting it and having associated non-alt text in a figcaption etc)
like the spec's example of a photo sharing site saying ""
(where the site knows nothing about the image, other than a description of it (which is not equivalent to the image itself))
sure, just wondering about the usefulness of the figcaption in that case then…

i have a drawing program that works, fine but since it is a mobile, app it broke.  noticed line 7 of the following makes the code fail http://pastebin.com/fvRpPFeu
need to figure out how to not use "context.beginPath();"  but lines are still anti-aliased
LoneStar99: It's not clear what that code is meant to be doing
It sounds like you're calling it each time the user clicks somewhere?
If you don't call beginPath, then every time you call lineTo you're making the current path get longer and longer
and each time you call stroke() you're re-drawing every line segment that's ever been added to that path
MikeSmith: am now
yes it is based o this code: http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.js
which might be what makes it look non-antialiased (because it's overdrawing the lines)
What you probably want is to do beginPath, and then moveTo with the *previous* mouse coordinates, and then lineTo with the current mouse coordinates
so that each time you're just drawing a single line between the previous and current mouse positions
Hmm, that example seems to do it wrong (it never resets so it'll stroke longer and longer paths)
the weird thing is that drawing works, without "context.beginPath();" but once uncommented, it fails to display
If you just call beginPath and then lineTo, it's not drawing a line from somewhere to somewhere
because you've only given it a single point
which is why you first need to moveTo the previous point
how would I moveTo previous point?
was chatting with another developer, and he said he does not even use "context.beginPath();"  to draw lines... how would I be able to do that?
You need to add some global variables and store ev._x and ev._y in them each time you draw, and then use those values in a moveTo the next time you draw (after beginPath and before lineTo)
If you don't use beginPath then you'll never reset to an empty path, so you'll have the problem of repeatedly drawing over the early parts of the path
(which is an easy mistake because it's hard to notice, but it eventually makes things go really slow and look ugly)
simply need to anti-alias anything drawn...  what is the best way?
this is the sample code working, but without anti-aliasing http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.html
It is antialiasing, but it's got this overdraw problem because it never resets the path
so if you move mouse a hundred times then the first part of the line will have been stroked a hundred times
and the antialiased grey gets drawn a hundred times and turns black
which is why it looks aliased
kinda confused...
If you say: ctx.strokeStyle = 'red'; ctx.moveTo(0, 0); ctx.lineTo(100, 0); ctx.stroke(); ctx.strokeStyle = 'green'; ctx.lineTo(100, 100); ctx.stroke();
then it will stroke the first line segment in red, and then it will stroke *both* line segments in green
because they're both still part of the current path
and that's what that example is doing (except it's a lot more than two line segments, and it's stroking them all in black)
